contentrichtext.text: In [[spatial statistics]], the '''empirical semivariance''' is described by :<math>\hat\gamma(h)=\frac{1}{2}\cdot\frac{1}{n(h)}\sum_{i=1}^{n(h)}(z(x_i+h)-z(x_i))^2</math> where ''z'' is a [[datum]] at a particular location, ''h'' is the distance between ordered data, and ''n''(''h'') is the number of paired data at a distance of ''h''. The semivariance is half the variance of the increments <math>z(x_i+h)-z(x_i)</math>, but the whole variance of z-values at given separation distance ''h'' (Bachmaier and Backes, 2008). A plot of semivariances versus distances between ordered data in a graph is known as a [[semivariogram]] rather than a [[variogram]]. Many authors call <math>2\hat\gamma(h)</math> a variogram, others use the terms variogram and semivariogram synonymously. However, Bachmaier and Backes (2008), who discussed this confusion, have shown that <math>\hat\gamma(h)</math> should be called a variogram, terms like semivariogram or semivariance should be avoided. ==See also== * [[Variance]] * [[Sampling variogram]] * [[Geostatistics]] * [[Kriging]] * [[Post-modern_portfolio_theory|Post-Modern Portfolio Theory]] == References == *Bachmaier, M and Backes, M, 2008, "Variogram or Semivariogram — Explaining the Variances in a Variogram".
